metadata.title: Interdisciplinary Knowledge Framework: Report of the Activity 2 of the ENRICH Project
metadata.description:
This report contains a synthesis of studies performed by staff inolved in the ENRICH Project – ‘Enhancing the Digital Inclusivity of Cultural and Natural Heritage’ – at the ‘Gabriele d’Annunzio’ University of Chieti-Pescara (UdA, Italy), at the University of Oviedo (UNIOVI, Spain), and at the University of Skövde (HiS, Sweden). ENRICH is a 14-month collaborative research activity funded by INGENIUM European University (co-funded by Erasmus+).

Data presented in this report are part of the project activity No.2 ‘Knowledge Framework’. It contains relevant interdisciplinary research data and elements for the design of inclusive digital solutions for the enhancement of cultural and natural heritage. It is organised into three distinct yet interrelated sections:

  1. Proposal for an Design Framework for the Digital Inclusivity of Cultural and Natural Heritage.
  2. Proposal for the Manufacturing Technologies for the Digital Inclusivity of Cultural and Natural Heritage. 
  3. A Modular Design Approach for Cultural Heritage Inclusion in Rural Village Setting.

The report is jointly developed by all team of the ENRICH Project and is publicly released under the Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike 4.0 International license (CC BY-NC-SA 4.0).

For more information, see:

  • https://sites.google.com/view/enrichproject/home
  • https://ingenium-university.eu/

data.title: Interdisciplinary Knowledge Framework: Report of the Activity 2 of the ENRICH Project

metadata.title: Figure 3 in An overview of Lepidoptera-host-parasitoid associations for southern Africa, including an illustrated report on 2 370 African Lepidoptera-host and 119 parasitoid-Lepidoptera associations

metadata.title: A MULHER NA JAULA DO CAPITAL: O CORPO FEMININO COMO CAMPO DE DISPUTA (Resumo Expandido)
metadata.description: Diante das constantes ameaças aos direitos das mulheres no Brasil, o presente trabalho objetiva, através de uma revisão bibliográfica, analisar os caminhos genealógicos do processo de dominação do feminino. Para isso, tomamos como partida os trabalhos de Foucault (1983, 1996, 1999), Preciado (2022a, 2022b), Wittig (2022) e Federici (2023), que permitem uma profunda compreensão acerca dos dispositivos de sexualidade e gênero que impactam a experiência feminina através de agressivas investidas contra o corpo. Apontamos, com base nessa fundamentação teórica, que o corpo feminino sofre constantes tentativas de controle com o propósito de estruturar e realizar a manutenção do capitalismo, com ferramentas que buscam o manejo de seus potenciais. Concluímos que, tendo em vista esse cenário engenhado desde a caça às bruxas, é necessário instigar um movimento de libertação das mulheres da jaula do capital, emancipando o feminino desses dispositivos enclausurantes.

creators.name: Imenes Nobre de Almeida, Maria Luiza

contributors.name: Imenes Nobre de Almeida, Maria Luiza

metadata.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)
metadata.description: This study aims to analyze the evolution of brain-based learning and its connection to instructional design in global higher education, utilizing a bibliometric analysis of publications in the Scopus and Web of Science databases from January 2013 to March 2024. The examination of the texts included VOSviewer, Excel, and Visme software.  The review recorded the development and geographical dispersion of the literature, while also delineating the ideological framework of BBL and instructional design in higher education.
metadata.method:
Explanation of existing data

The timeframe selected for this evaluation is the past decade, which spans from January 2013 to March 2024, comprising a decade and three months. Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) were the databases employed, as they are the most frequently employed for bibliometric analysis (Pranckutė, 2021). The review protocol was designed based on the type of study. The methodology and guidelines recommended by the Joanna Briggs Institute (Peters et al., 2020) as cited in Medina-Córdoba et al. (2023) were followed, as well as the PRISMA reporting guidelines "Extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA-ScR)" (Tricco et al., 2018 cited by Medina-Córdoba et al. 2023).

 

Data collection procedures

Source identification for this study will be conducted according to the Preferred Reporting Criteria for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines, which detail procedures for identifying papers for inclusion in systematic analyses of research reviews (Page et al., 2021). The review will focus on articles published in journals indexed in Scopus and Web of Science (WOS) in both English and Spanish. Conference papers, conference proceedings, books and book chapters will be excluded, since articles from peer-reviewed journals go through a more rigorous publication process and are considered more reliable in the academic field (Hallinger, 2020).

 

Stopping rule

The size of the articles will be controlled by the number of articles that the time frame chosen for this scoping review yields, which covers the last ten years (January 2013 to March 2024 - one decade and 3 months) in the databases that will be used, Scopus and Web of Science (WOS).

data.title: Evolution of BBL in Instructional Design in Higher Education: Scoping review (2013-2024)

metadata.title: Woodsia kungiana Li Bing Zhang, T. N. Lu & X. F. Gao 2019, sp. nov.
metadata.description:
Woodsia kungiana Li Bing Zhang, T.N.Lu & X.F.Gao, sp. nov. Fig. 1.

Type:— CHINA. Sichuan Province: Kangding County, Sanhe Township, Pengta Village, 30.4420766 N, 102.361078 E, elev. 4080 m, 15 August, 2017. Gao Xin-Fen & Yang Yan THP-KD-4887 (holotype CDBI!, isotype CDBI!)

Diagnosis:—This new species is most similar to Woodsia cycloloba Handel-Mazzetti (1929: 19) in having creeping rhizomes, stipes blackish purple, lustrous and brittle, and laminae 1-pinnate with conform apex, but the new species has rachises with articulate hairs and linear-filiform scales, adaxial laminar surface and margins with a few articulate hairs, and indusia serrated and cup-like; in contrast, the latter has rachises with articulate hairs but rarely with linear-filiform scales, adaxial laminar surface and margins with dense articulate hairs, and indusia absent.

Plants 1.5–6 cm tall. Roots to 13 cm long, 0.25–0.5 mm in diam. Rhizomes creeping, ca. 0.5 cm wide, scaly; scales often uniformly brown and bicolored with dark central stripe and pale brown margins, glossy, lanceolate, 0.1–0.5 × 1–2 mm, basally attached, entire to irregularly toothed, tips filiform. Fronds not clustered; stipe continuous (lacking articulation), black-purple, glossy, fragile, brittle, short, the longest 3 cm, ca. 0.4 mm wide, scales on lower part similar to those on rhizome, with sparse articulate hairs, articulate hairs on upper part linear-filiform, 0.1–0.4 × 1.5–2.5 mm, entire; laminae 1–pinnate, lanceolate, 1.2–2.5 × 0.7–1.5 cm, herbaceous, brownish-dull green when dried, not reduced at base, the biggest the lowest or middle, terminal pinna apex conform, both sides of laminae with articulate hairs; rachis with articulate hairs and linear-filiform scales; pinnae often (2–)4(–5) pairs, rounded or orbiculate, 0.6–1.9 × 0.4–1.5 cm, sessile, alternate to sub-opposite, base truncate-cordate, apex rounded or obtuse, margin entire to undulate, rarely slightly crenate; veins onceforked, reaching or almost reaching to margin. Sori orbicular, medial, 4–9 per pinna; sporangia large, ca. 0.5 mm in diameter, brown, membranous, globose; indusia serrated, cup-like or sometimes sori exindusiate. Spores large ca. 0.09 mm, brown to dark brown.

Etymology:— In honor of the late Prof. Hsian-Shiu Kung based at the herbarium CDBI, a specialist of pteridophytes and the author of Flora Sichuanica vol. 6 (pteridophytes; Kung 1988). Together with colleagues, he also described Woodsia kangdingensis H. S. Kung, Li Bing Zhang & X. S. Guo (1995: 421). Under his supervision the senior author L.B.Z. obtained his degree of M.Sc. in 1990.

Geographical distribution:— Woodsia kungiana is currently known from three counties (Baoxing, Dujiangyan, Kangding) in Sichuan, China.

Notes:— Morphologically, Woodsia kungiana is obviously a member of W. subg. Eriosorus (Ching 1932: 134) Shmakov (2003: 59). This subgenus is characterized by having stipe and rachis castaneous, stipes not articulate (but continuous), stipe scales bicolorous, lamina apex conform, and sori exindusiate or with hairy indusia, and is recognized in a recent classification (Lu et al., submitted). Phylogenetically W. kungiana was resolved as sister to W. cycloloba. Zhang et al. (2013) described W. cycloloba as “indusia absent or composed of ciliate, platelike, small lobes”. However, our microscopic examination of three accessions of W. cycloloba showed that the sori of W. cycloloba are exindusiate, consistent with the description in the protologue (Handel-Mazzetti 1929).

Additional material examined:— CHINA. Sichuan Province: Baoxing (Mupin), Mt. Jiajin, elev. 4050 m, Liang Zhang & J. A. van de Veire 1529 (CDBI!). Sichuan Province: Dujiangyan, Bo Xu et al. 7302 (CDBI!).
